div1.p: You cannot possibly know how much I appreciate your letter and comments. I know how much time all that takes, and you are wonderful to do it. Bower is reading your comments over now for the third time, and he keeps looking up to say "You must be careful with these papers. You must not let anything happen to them."

When I have revised the chapter I will send it back to you just to be sure — I want very much to have everything I write about you true as well as factual, and that is why it's good you can see it and make corrections. As you say, this chapter suffers from being part of a dissertation. It's out of focus to begin with because it has to be keyed to speech, and that throws the emphasis to your speaking and your criticism. That is all wrong, of course, but it's the only way in the dissertation. But I'd like the distortion to be as slight as possible, the part that is included must be true to the spirit and mood. I'd redo the P-D paragraph; when I read it over I saw what you meant. Those are the things I want to catch. I understood the situation, but I didn't see what my sketchy version implied. I can't tell the whole story till the biography, but I'll help it.

The biography chapter suffers a little too because some of the material that might go into it I am reserving for other chapters. The Edwin Markhham comments, for example, the Speyer reception, and a lot of things like that go into the readings chapter. I'm enclosing Chapter II, which takes up your rehtorical theory. Chapter III, now under way, is an analysis of your speaking according to the classical five canons. It is the of the speaking part, as dissertations go, but I'm separating the lectures for Chapter IV because they are a chapter themselves. Chapter V will be readings. Your practice is Aristotelian; you may be surprised at how many of Aristotle's lines of argument you used. You could have written a treatise on rhetoric — but the Songs were more important. I'm glad you did exactly what you did.

In the last part I think I will add the statement from DVicki Dewey's mother to Frances McCurdy that coming to Missouri was worth it for the opportunity to meet you and be in your class. You are right
66d
about "flaming" socialist — it's a breach of style besides being misleading. I should do something to keep the word socialist from setting up wrong connotations; you were never a socialist as most people define the term in these times. Don't you think I should delete it altogether unless I can make clear that it really meant anti-materialistic humanitarian — or is that redundant?

I will change the traditionalism too. Words like that can carry overtones because of their label -gravity. It's not a precise contrast anyway; I'll reword. Pessimism is better than cynicism for Robinson. I'll change that. It grew on him, didn't it? I've been reading his poetry to follow your reviews of it, and his later poems have a different tone from the early ones. The Princeton library, by the way, is looking for your letters from Robinson. The man there thinks it's a shame they aren't all together, and he has promised to let me know if he finds any trace.

Mrs. Winkelman wrote me that a bunch of old Nebraska papers have turned up in somebody's attic in Wismer, and she is going to comb them for articles about you and send me facsimiles. I'm enclosing a poem she sent that may be yours. If you remember it, it's interesting to know, because you were only 15 — it's 1896. She also sent a small notice of your marriage in the West Point Republican and I'd like to add a few sentences from it to the chapter if you wouldn't mind. They are to the effect that your writing had "enhanced the glory" of your town country and state, and that this marriage was a to increase the light of art and literature."

I don't want to forget to tell you about our visit with Mr. Chaffee. He and the Skillings were very much pleased that you had sent the Cycle. They showed it to me and asked all sorts of questions about you. They are all reading the Cycle, and you are adding a glow to their lives. You would like Mr. Skillings. He is confined to a hospital bed, and he's pretty weak, but he is alert and interested in everything. He is really an enthusiast on the Indian Wars, and knows a good bit about Custer and the various events of the war. They had not yet read the Song of the Indian Wars, and I wish I could be there
66e
when they do to see their faces. Mr. Skillings rather thinks Reno was made a scapegoat in the Custer fight business — we had a good time talking about it.

Mr. Chaffee said something I want to ask you about too. He says Williams Jennings Bryan used to come to Wayne in the summers and teach at Waynethe college; he stayed at the Chaffees. Apparently he was a friend of Dr. Pile. Do you remember anything about this? Did you ever meet him?

You are certainly right about patterns. I have felt it too in my life, although I didn't have an assignment like yours — just a sense that I had something to do in the world that I was being prepared for. It's a strange feeling that can't be expressed to other people except very rarely, because most would think such a feeling "queer." Much more than I can explain I feel a deep down current of — well, sympathy is the closest word, but it's not exact — for you and Mrs. Neihardt. Bower feels it too — a psychic kinship as if we knew the same things, or at least some of the same things. I could write a book about Mrs. Neihardt — when I have read some of the letters she wrote to the girls I have loved her and them and my own daughters all in the same, pulse-beat. I'm not unique in this — hundreds of years from now other people will read the letters and feel the same way. You are both gifts to the world in a sense; each of you is all men or all women without losing a jot of your own individuality. It has given you a responsibility that you met and accepted, and I can never see that vanity in at all. I simply cannot see vanity in anything have ever said or done or thought. You respect your work, that's all, and you should.

This is a volume, but I did want to thank you and bring you up to date on our visits with Mr. Chaffee. Will go up to see him again, and I still have some letters out that I'll report or when I get answers.
Our best to everyone, and please read this chapter at your leisure. The third one will take a little time yet.
